segments.text: Dr. Bill Peters, who is the head of the Department of Education Curriculum and Instruction and has been at Texas A&M since 1981.
And Dr. Peters, I hope you're going to share with me a few of the changes that have occurred since you have been here.
And again, you are one of my newer interviewees.
But maybe your perceptions of what has caused some of these major changes.
you know, how you feel about where we're going.
We'll go from the past to the present to the future, if that's okay.
And just give me, first of all, changes within the college and then, or if you want to, specifically just within your department.

As department head, you're seeing, you know, the department and the college from a totally different, because you have interaction with the dean and it's, you know, I'm kind of peeking in through little windows and doors.
I don't
I'm not a part of the whole system or the organization.
Well, I came to Texas A&M University from the University of Kentucky, where I had chaired a similar department.
And I was at that institution for 13 years.
And I served under the leadership of George Denemark.
And George Denemark was a very well-known leader in teacher education.
And I felt very, very fortunate.
to move from the leadership of George Gennemer to the leadership of Dean.
How did Dean find you?
Or was it Dean Corrigan?
Yes, Dean Corrigan.
This is rather an interesting story.
And I guess I could share it as an anecdote, perhaps, as part of how this occurred.
I was completing my first term at the University of Kentucky.

And in October, as chair of the Department of Curriculum and Instruction at Kentucky, I received a notice, as I do from a number of institutions, that there was an opening for head of the Department of Curriculum and Instruction at Texas A&M University.
And frankly, I was impressed just with
the announcement itself.
It was very well written.
It had a statement about the community.
It was on very fine paper.
It was the type of thing that's different from the kind of announcement that normally passes over one's desk.
And I guess I would say that I wasn't struck in terms of saying this is something I'm going to apply for, but I was rather struck by the advertisement and
the fact that it was a Texas A&M University, but an institution about which I knew very little.
And as I normally do, I listed it on our bulletin board and really gave not much further thought to it, except that it was the year that I was entering into my review.
And now I'm, I guess I'm going to be getting a little bit into my personality now, but

I guess I dismissed that announcement because what I did not want to have perceived was any kind of perception that I was thinking about going to another institution as a way to sort of get a more favorable review, shall we say.
And I was very happy at Kentucky.
I began my career there as an assistant professor and moved through the ranks.
In three years, I was an associate professor, and then I became a full professor and so forth.
And working under George Denimart's leadership, I was very, very happy.
There were some rumors about George thinking about retiring.
And I guess there were a couple of subconscious elements that were functioning within me that perhaps made me
subconsciously think about a move, but not really thinking about one.
Well, I just dismissed it from my mind, to be honest with you.
In early spring, a second announcement from Texas A&M University crossed my desk because the search was reopened.
And I thought, well, this is curious.
Apparently, they have not found someone for that position.
Who was department head then?
Or was it an interim?
David David was the interim department head.
Robert Schutz had had a heart attack.
And David David was serving as interim head.
I mentioned at dinner one evening, my children, my son in particular, was still in high school.
And I mentioned this at the dinner table.
to my wife, I said, that's curious, I have another announcement that passed my desk about Texas A&M University, and no one really knew too much about the university.
And my son said, Dad, you know, it's a warm climate, why don't you just go ahead and apply for that job and see what would happen?
Now, at that time, I had, my review had been completed, and I had received a favorable review and was reappointed for another term as chair of the department.
That, of course, took away any semblance of my attempt to use any leverage.
I still said, well, you know, I'm still happy.
We like Lexington.
It's a pretty part of the country, and so forth.
And I dismissed it again.
My daughter was at the University of Virginia at that time.
And I can't exactly remember the date, but it was about the first week in May, perhaps, when we needed to get a U-Haul.
to go to the University of Virginia to pack up her things to bring her home for summer.
The deadline for applying for this position was something like May 15.
And this was either May 13 or May 14.
And as we were packing to leave, my son said, dad, did you ever send that application in?
And I said, no, I didn't.
But I have it all done.
But I said, I think the deadline is probably tomorrow or the next day, so, and we're busy, we're trying to move.
And he said, look, why don't we nail it on the way leaving for picking up Vicki?
And I did.
And he said, it may be postmarked.
And I said, because if it isn't postmarked by the deadline, it can't be considered.
Well, we went on our journey to pick up my daughter from the University of Virginia, and Patrick came back.
got back, I believe it was on Monday, and I was returning to U-Haul, and came back home, and my wife said, Bill, you have a call from Texas.
And I said, oh, certainly I have a call from Texas.
Well, it was Brian Cole.
And Brian called to see if indeed I was sincere about my application.
And I said, yes, I was sincere about my application.
That's why I forwarded it.
And he said, well, we would be interested in having you come to visit with us on campus.
I was in the midst of recruiting for Kentucky at that time.
And I also had some other rather vital things that I had to get done.
So I explained to him that my

the time I could come to be rather limited, but I could come, I couldn't arrive until like 11 o'clock on one evening because of the flight arrangements, and would be able to spend a day and a half or so, which was the time they wanted.
In the meantime, I, of course, returned to my office, and I had a few faculty members who came in to see me and said, Bill Peters, what are you about?
And I said, what do you mean?
Well, obviously, there had been some
telephone calls made from this institution to my, at that time, home institution.
And I said, well, I'm just really going down to look.
And I had previous to this mentioned to Dean Denimer that I had received this second notice, and I said I might apply.
And his comment to me was, Bill, you can go and look, but don't you dare leave, which I felt very good about.
Of course, I had just had favorable review and so forth.
Well, I came down, and everything just happened very rapidly.
And I accepted the position here.
I could tell you another little story, and I don't know if it should go on tape or not.
But I came down here for an interview.
And at that time, they were also interviewing for reading positions.
And Dr. Pat Alexander was being interviewed here.
And at breakfast on the day I was being interviewed, she was also at breakfast at another table.
And I think it may be David David who wanted to introduce me to her.

And of course, what David David did not know at that time was that I was flying back to Kentucky and would be picking up Pat at the airport in Lexington because she was being interviewed for our reading position at that institution.
Isn't that funny?
And that's exactly what occurred.
I interviewed her and told her she must remember I'm interviewing for the University of Kentucky.
And we both ended up here.
Isn't that interesting?
Well, you have, is it the largest department in the university?
Yes, one of the largest.
How many in your staff?
How many in the staff?
I mean, how many, like, people?
over 2,000 students in the department.
And if you include those individuals who are interested in certification outside of the college, we run about 2,400 students.
And our faculty and staff total about 100 in the department.
So in fact, our department is really larger than some colleges of education.
University of Oklahoma, for example, has something like 38 full-time
tenure track back.
So really, by the time you came here, a lot of the major things had already occurred.
Of course, they had already made the transition to the new administration.
Yes, first year.
So you have not experienced any of the drastic, you are now probably in the most, in the biggest upheaval type changes, would you say?
Yes, I guess I would.
Let me say that when I came here, the department probably was half the size it is now.
I think we had about eleven or twelve hundred students.
So what has happened since I've been here is an enormous increase in student enrollment in our department.
And what is that based on, or what is that attributed to?
Well, it's attributed to a number of things.
First, I think it's attributed to the quality of our teacher preparation program.
Second, I think it's attributed to the quality
of the student population at Texas A&M University.
Third, I think it's attributed to our growing national reputation.
Tell me how we have gotten that growing national reputation.
What has really been the primary...
First is the fact that we have a man like Dean Corrigan as dean of this college.
And he has been a respected educator prior to coming to Texas A&M University.
However, he has increased, I think, his visibility nationally and internationally because of his sincere professional interest in education.
To put it another way, Kim Corrigan is not the kind of individual who is doing something to gain more stature for himself.
He does it out of the sincere interest for those who are going to benefit by what he thinks he can achieve.
I think that makes quite a difference because
what he has to say is perceived as being said to further and to make better the lives of our young people.
As opposed to furthering, he's putting it better in his hand.
He'd use a colloquialism.
I think that the
And this may get into some of the other points that you might be raising a little later on.
Well, that's OK.
They can be in it.
Sure, sure.
No problem.
Is the fact that what I'm very pleased about in regard to our department is the department's growing national reputation.
And I think that is due.
Now, some people would look upon this negatively as opposed to positively.
I need to share with you that my entire career has been spent in major research institutions.
And so I come from that mentality.
And I think you need to have that context.
So that when I came to Texas A&M University, I came from that mentality, which said that there is not a dichotomy between outstanding teaching and outstanding research.
Because in teacher education,
I don't see how you can be on the cutting edge of teacher education unless you're on the cutting edge of research, and they support one another.
They are not contradictory.
I think some of our best instructors, and I could name a few if you wanted me to, but as illustrative of this, I think some of our best instructors are the best researchers.
They go hand in hand.
We were just talking earlier about Pat Alexander.
That's an interesting point.
Pat Alexander now has a Spencer Fellowship.
And that is highly competitive, and it's given by the National Academy of Education at Harvard University.
She has a $25,000 grant.
And the manner in which you get that grant is by submitting a research proposal.
And it is reviewed by the National Academy.
And you gain that grant if they feel that your research is going to truly make an impact on the field of education.
What is she researching?
What is her area?
She's looking at domain-specific cognition versus the subject-specific matter.
Ooh.
It's really metacognition is what she's getting into.
Okay.
Metacognition.
Now, you probably are aware of the fact that she just was one of the university-level recipients of the Outstanding Teaching Award by the Association of Former Students.
Oh, yes, very definitely.
That was wonderful.
So what I'm saying, I think,
It's illustrated by Pat.
She is an outstanding teacher and an outstanding researcher.
Another individual in our department, just not to be sexist, John Denton.
And John Denton is a very demanding, as Pat is a very demanding instructor, but a highly respected, sought-after instructor who also is highly productive in research.
The point I'm making is that...
I know what you're...
This is going to be on tape, but I'm going to say it anyway.
I came here in August.
I already had to begin the promotion and tenure review process in the department.
I brought with me
a certain mentality of promotion and tenure.
And what I brought with me was the fact that when one was going to be promoted and tenured, what you did was to put together a dossier.
And in your dossier were examples of supporting your teaching activities, your service activities, and your research activities.
You also included reprints of your publications.
In addition, the department head sought letters of reference from individuals who were respected in the nation and outside the institution.
So there were a few people.
Letters of reference?
Letters of reference for support.
of promotion and tenure of individuals.
Based on these dossiers?
Well, based on a vitae.
A vitae, OK. All right, all right.
You can't send the whole dossier.
Right.

Now, that meant when I came here, when I had these names of these individuals about whom I knew very little because I was in the institution, I simply met with them and shared, you know, now you'll get your dossier together.
And if you want to give me a couple names of people you know, but I'm going to select some individuals in the nation who are in your field.
secure letters of reference.
Of course, they sat there just as you are, smiling.
And of course, from my perception, I just assumed that this was routine, when in fact it wasn't.
It had not been routine, which I guess would begin to show a change that was occurring in the institution, a part of which I was.
I was part of that change.
But it was strictly departmental, not
At that point, it was departmental.
And I didn't realize that.
So when I sent out my letters of reference and they came back and so forth, when I put together my letter from the department in supporting it, I indicated these letters of reference.
Well, now at that time, all we had to do was forward this letter from the department in which we supported or did not support the recommendation for promotion and or tenure.
And I went to the college and then went forward from the college.
No materials were required at that time other than this letter, although I did support it with these letters of reference.
I don't know if you are aware of the procedures we now follow, but the procedures that we began to use in the department are very similar to
the promotion and tenure procedures that now have been instituted by the central administration so that all faculty who are up for promotion and tenure must have a dossier.
It's not called for by the central administration, but it's there, and it includes many of the pieces of material that I just cited.
And that dossier is reviewed by the promotion and tenure committee as well as by the department head.
It requires a minimum of three letters outside
at the university.
And those three letters must be from individuals who are at least at the rank to which the person wants to be promoted.
So that, I guess what I'm saying is that have I seen change at this institution?
I have seen a great deal of change at this institution in regard to where it has moved in terms of faculty review for promotion and tenure.
So then we could answer, that would be an answer possibly to one of
of your contributions in number nine, because you already came with that idea, and it sort of evolved.
Perhaps it had something to do with the way it is now structured.

I don't want to be so bold as to say it was a contribution, but let me say that one of the first things we did, which I'd be glad to provide you if you'd like, is to put together an annual evaluation document
And that came out in February of 82.
Remember, I came here in August.
And in March of 82, we put a promotion and tenure document together.
Because one of the things that I recognized when I came here is that there was nothing in it.
This is for the whole college, not for them.
You're still talking department.
OK, I'm sorry.
You want me to talk to partners?

Yes, but I mean, I wondered how it might have influenced, because again, I'm looking at the department and how the external environment of the college and then the external environment of the university.
So maybe how, if there's anything that fits all.
Since there was very little in writing, and one of the things that I felt very strongly about is that faculty, I believe we have to have expectations, and those expectations need to be
But at the same time, it's clear that faculty have known what those expectations are.
Now, then it's a question of knowing those expectations, have you met them?
And there was a faculty committee, a faculty evaluation committee,
that put together these documents.
I served as an ad hoc member of the committee.
But it is a faculty committee document, both of those.
And if you'd like copies of those, I'd share them.
I would, surely.
And in the sense of what you're saying, in retrospect, I guess perhaps they were one of the earliest documents in the college.
Because Ernie Goetz and the faculty advisory council about a year ago began to interview
department heads in regard to what criteria do they have?
Were they written down?
And this is all an outgrowth, I think, of the Faculty Senate, which was formulated.
And our documents, as I indicated, were dated 1982.
And I think they're probably the earlier documents in the count.
And other departments have formulated their documents.
And does there continue, then, to be total autonomy in that every department, according to the department heads,
criteria just follows?
In other words, everybody's doing their own thing as far as this type of document?
Within the general guidelines of the college.
See, that's part of what has occurred.
What the Parent and Staff Advisory Council is trying to do and has tried to do is to find out what each department is doing.
And if there are discrepancies, then they want to be able to identify those so that there can be a college review
committee that will understand where each of the departments is coming from.

So you really answered that question that I had about teaching research and service, you know, through what you just shared, because that is the way, in your perception, and most everybody else is feeling that, you know, there's pressure to do research, but if you're doing research, you know, you can't do justice to teaching and vice versa.
Absolutely.
Now, it's possible for a faculty member
to have a modified role responsibility.
In other words, in our document, when you review our document, you'll see that a faculty member could come in to talk to me and say, Bill, I really need to do a lot of research in the coming year.
Could you reduce my instructional load by one course?
if we can see that we can cover our staffing.
And I'd say, yes, we can do that.
Then the role responsibility has shifted.
And then your evaluation at the end of the year would be based on that modification of role.

Now, if you were, let's say you were a new assistant professor coming in to me, and you said to me, you wanted to, if it's possible, you'd like to really, you enjoy teaching so much, you'd like to do teaching and have your research
component practically just 10%.
But I would say to you is, well, let's think that one over.
Let's talk in terms of your probationary period and what the expectations might be.
Now, do you think it would be wise, if we went this route, do you think it would be wise for you to do that at this point?
What would be the impact of that next year and the year after?
Because, from my point of view, it would be a disservice to the individual
Now, because your department has grown so tremendously, do you teach classes all the time?
So you always have taught?
Always have.
Okay.
How has it affected not only your work with students, but do you get a feedback from your faculty as to whether or not they're able?
making great numbers, or it's impeding their work with students and giving them the attention.
And do you have a limit, for example, on how many committees people can chair, or how many graduate students they can advise in that kind of thing?
Yes.
We instituted, through our graduate faculty, a set of criteria in terms of the number of chairs that you could have in regard to PhD, DD, the number
So we have put a limitation on that because that was getting out of hand also.
Let me share with you that my role has been tremendously pushed into a management role.
With the increases that we have had and the limited resources, frankly, that we've received
It has been, my time has to be spent almost entirely in managing resources.
And frankly, I'm very pleased with the manner in which we have been able to function within this stroke pattern.
By managing resources, are you talking about space and money, just everything?
I'm talking about staffing.
I'm talking about space.
I'm talking about operating expenses, I'm talking about travel, I'm talking about research.
The October 1986 issue of Teacher Education, you're probably aware of this article.
Productivity of faculty in higher education institutions.
This is based on the number of articles
produced, now this is in teacher education, produced in major teacher education journals.

And number of presentations made at teacher education organizations like the Association of Teacher Educations, the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education, the American Educational Research Association.
If you want to look, look at where Texas A&M ranks.
And what I'm pleased with is that
although obviously this means a survey of all the college faculty, in regard to teacher education, my faculty is heavily involved in teacher education, as opposed to...
I'm trying to think of an area.
industrial education or something like that.

So that when it comes to making presentations about how are you preparing teachers, what are the best strategies, instructional strategies, and so forth, and research in those domains, I would say that our faculty are in a large bulk of this group.
I think that's incredible.
And now, is there much, in your faculty, much collaboration with people in other departments or within
The department with each other, there is?
As much as you'd like, or is there ever as much?
Part of this is coming from Dean's initial structure of the college in regard to its inquiry groups.
And I think you're aware of the inquiry groups.
And so I think one of the things Dean has tried to do is to cut down the departmental barriers to the degree possible.
When I first came here, it was clear to me that we were highly departmentalized.
To put it another way, the faculty was very much oriented toward its own department.
And I think there's been quite a change in that regard.
As department, obviously, I have to try to get the greatest resources I can for my department.
had to struggle over these years because of this enormous growth that we've experienced.
And I feel that Dean has been open to all departments in regard to their needs.
And obviously, we all feel like we could get a little bit more.
But I think in terms of what we've gotten, and some of this has been central administration, like operating expenses, we simply haven't received increases in operating expenses.
And that's something the central administration basically deals with.
So that's not something that is unfair in the college, if you understand what I'm saying.
And that's why I feel very strongly that we've done very well in managing when we can have this kind of research productivity.
At the same time, we are still serving our students.
Now, that's becoming more and more a problem.
We just began pre-registration, and I already have a number of classes that are closed.
Now, I have students sign a little slip in the outer office and what class they want and why they need it.
Here I have an example of one of the burdens of management that I have had to assume.
We do not...
